availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: William Norvell (Carlisle, Kentucky, KY Rep, judge and attorney)

body.p: Carlisle, Kentucky, politician, judge and attorney. Kentucky native. Married to Emily G. Summers Norvell in Nicholas County, Kentucky, on March 15, 1836. Father of Lucy S. Norvell, Joseph Norvell, John Norvell, Jenny P. Norvell, Alice R. Norvell, and Mattie E. Norvell. Attorney in Nicholas County in 1850. Owned one enslaved person in Nicholas County in 1850. Represented Nicholas County in the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Kentucky in 1833. Represented Nicholas County in the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Kentucky in 1835. Attorney in Carlisle in 1860. Owned three enslaved persons in Nicholas County in 1860. Judge in Nicholas County from 1860 to 1861.

ab.bibl:
Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Nicholas, District 2, p. 391A.
Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Slave Schedules, Kentucky, Nicholas, District 2, p. 1.

Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Slave Schedules, Kentucky, Nicholas, Carlisle, p.137A.
Kentucky Marriage Records, Madison County Courthouse, Richmond, Kentucky, Nicholas County Marriages, Film #000252402, p. 149.
Find A Grave, "William Norvell (1803-1875)," Memorial #71831491, https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/71831491 (accessed March 19, 2020).
Lewis Collins and Richard H. Collins, Collins' Historical Sketches of Kentucky, vol. 1 (Covington, KY: Collins & Co., 1874), 651.
The Biographical Encyclopaedia of Kentucky of the Dead and Living Men of the Nineteenth Century (Cincinnati, OH: J.M. Armstrong & Company, 1878), 778.
